title: Having an IUD is Great. Getting One Can Be Terrible Just Can't Get Enough?
content: The appeal of the IUD is undeniable: When you can get pregnant and donâ€™t want to, 10 baby-free years feels like a miracle, something youâ€™d be willing to suffer for at least a little. But for a lot of patients, the pain that comes with an IUD insertion is way more than â€œa little.â€ And worse, the pain is often downplayed by providersâ€”if itâ€™s even addressed at all. When Rep. Amy Walen (D-48) accompanied a young woman to an insertion appointment, she found this lack of pain control horrifying. So horrifying that sheâ€™s prefiled a bill for the upcoming 2025 legislative session addressing it. House Bill 1077 would require clinicians to discuss pain management with patients before IUD insertions. Walen hopes her bill will raise awareness about the very real pain that can accompany this extremely routine procedure: IUDs are one of the most popular forms of long-acting birth control on the market. She wants to keep other people from experiencing the intense pain she witnessed in the patient she accompanied, whose pain was intense and unrelenting. â€œIt was really, really upsetting how painful it was for her,â€ said Walen. With state legislatures across the country understandably focused on abortion access since the reversal of Roe v. Wade, itâ€™s unusual to see policies like Walenâ€™s, which specifically focus on IUDs. But maybe it shouldnâ€™t be. If youâ€™ve ever gotten an IUDâ€”or talked to a fellow drunk girl in a bathroom line for just a little too longâ€”the pain that can accompany an insertion is not new information. When I surveyed IUD usersâ€”or would-be usersâ€”about their experiences most recently, I was immediately flooded with responses describing â€œmind-bending pain,â€ prolonged failed insertion attempts, repeated uses of the word â€œbrutal,â€ and comparisons to things like â€œa small dragon â€¦ trying to claw out of my body for 24-36 hours.â€ These were concerning, but they were also deeply familiar. Stories like these are the subject of casual conversations over brunch or a beer. One friend of mine described pain that lingered for days after her insertion. Another, who fainted during her appointment, attempted to put a positive spin on things: â€œOne shining silver lining was my nurse was a hot dyke and caught me when I fell off the table and I woke up in her arms,â€ she said. Removal was memorably bad, too, for a former colleague of mine. â€œWhen having it extracted, my doctor (and an intern) couldnâ€™t get it out,â€ she said. â€œHe spent 30 or 45 minutes yanking on it from various angles as I tried not to scream.â€ My editor knows a woman whose first IUD insertion was so painful that years later, when she returned to get it replaced, she had a full-blown panic attack. Her body was so tense that they weren't able to safely complete the procedure. Even women whoâ€™ve given birth describe the pain of IUD insertion on particularly gnarly terms. Elinor Jones, better known as the celebrity gossip columnist at our sister paper the Mercury, described an insertion attempt that had to be stopped because it was so painful it was â€œlike knives.â€ Annie Jurrens, whoâ€™s been through two unmedicated births, described her IUD insertion as one of â€œacute pain, like being stabbed in an internal organ.â€ Given the grim state of reproductive health care in America, stories like theseâ€”where things really devolved, but no one died or was permanently injuredâ€”might seem like minor inconveniences, hot nurse or not. And juxtaposed with the horrors visited upon people who had first-generation IUDs like the infamous Dalkon Shield, perhaps they are. A claw-like device with a sci-fi name, the Dalkon Shieldâ€™s design led so many users to develop pelvic inflammatory disease that it became the subject of one of the largest tort liability cases in history. Itâ€™s an unqualified good thing that the Dalkon Shield is off the market, but its existence seems to have set the bar in hell for future IUD experiences. You wouldnâ€™t know this from the next-gen IUDsâ€™ branding, ensconced in the soft focus of marketplace feminism, with imaginary girlsâ€™ names that sound like theyâ€™re written in cursive on a wooden sign inside HomeGoods: Skyla, Mirena, Kyleena. (The eminently practical ParaGard is the only exception to this: As the oldest and only non-hormonal option in the gang, the copper T is like the used Subaru hatchback of IUDs, and I mean that as the highest praise.) Despite this rosy marketingâ€”and the very real pain they feltâ€”the IUD users I spoke to said they received little or no advance warning that their procedures might be painful. Some were told just to take ibuprofen beforehand, others werenâ€™t even given that advice. One was told scheduling the insertion during her period would make it easier, â€œbut it just resulted in the whole fiasco being an absolute bloodbath,â€ she said. Thereâ€™s a reason for this bizarro dissonance between brutal patient experiences and provider attitudes toward pain management and support: Research suggests that patients and providers perceive the pain of IUD insertion differently. A 2015 study published in The European Journal of Contraception & Reproductive Health Care found that while most IUD insertions â€œappeared acceptable to most patients,â€ providers â€œtended to underestimate the degree of pain experienced by their patients during IUD insertion procedures.â€ That could be changing. Earlier this year, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention updated its guidelines for clinicians inserting IUDs to encourage conversations about pain management with patients before the speculum comes out. The CDC now recommends the use of topical or injected lidocaine, which numbs the cervix. Misoprostol, also used in medication abortions, may be helpful for some patients, but itâ€™s not suggested for typical use. Itâ€™s not clear what role, if any, legislative policies like Walenâ€™s will have in advancing these updated clinical guidelines, beyond drawing attention to them. Sarah Prager, an abortion provider in Seattle, was skeptical of the approach. â€œThere already exists a lot of guidance around offering/providing pain management for IUD insertions (including newer advice from the CDC within the Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC) for Contraception Use (published updates this year),â€ she said. â€œI 100% agree expanded options for pain management should be offered/available, but I disagree that legislation is the appropriate vehicle for achieving this.â€ But one thing is always worth remembering: A good doctor (the kind you deserve) will realize youâ€™re in pain, and do something about it. â€œI was ready to power through,â€ said Jones. â€œI am grateful for my (female) doctor being like â€˜You are in too much pain and I donâ€™t recommend continuing.â€™â€ But if youâ€™re at the doctorâ€™s office and something is painful, youâ€™re allowed to speak up.

title: US District Court Judge Blocks Trump Order on Gender Affirming Care, Says It Would Not â€œSurvive Judicial Scrutinyâ€ Just Can't Get Enough?
content: US District Court Judge Lauren King today temporarily blocked President Donald Trumpâ€™s executive order to withhold all federal funding for gender-affirming care for people under age 19 from taking effect in Washington, Oregon and Minnesotaâ€”the three states that filed suit against the Trump administration last week. The order is blocked for the next 14 days. King, a Biden appointee, said Trumpâ€™s executive order intended to erase transgender people and â€œblatantly discriminated against trans youth.â€ The decision came less than 24 hours after a judge in Maryland temporarily blocked the order nationwide. King believed that Trumpâ€™s executive orderâ€”titled â€œProtecting Children From Chemical and Surgical Mutilationâ€â€” was not likely to â€œsurvive judicial scrutinyâ€ because it subverted the power of Congress to distribute money for potentially lifesaving gender-affirming care and violated equal protection under the 5th Amendment by not funding trans health care, while continuing to fund the same, or similar treatments, for cisgender children. Judge Kingâ€™s temporary restraining order comes exactly one week after Washington Attorney General Nick Brown sued over Trumpâ€™s order. As AG Brown said at a news conference announcing the suit, the order not only threatened to defund hospitals and research institutions that provided this care, but possibly prosecute providers. Transgender people across the country have lost care because doctors and hospitals took those threats seriously, including Seattle Childrenâ€™s Hospital, which last week postponed a trans teenâ€™s masculinizing top surgery the night before it was scheduled, attracting protest from trans people, parents of trans kids, and their supporters. During the hearing, Washington Deputy Solicitor General Tera Heintz argued Trumpâ€™s order was â€œopen and unapologetic bigotryâ€ that rejected the overwhelming medical consensus that gender-affirming care is safe and effective for children. She read comments from a plaintiff in the case, a doctor who has treated hundreds of trans children, and remains anonymous for fear of retribution.â€œThere are going to be young people who take their lives if they can no longer receive this care,â€ she read. â€œWithout access to this care, transgender adolescents will dieâ€”I am certain of it.â€ Heintz said the statesâ€™ lawyers had introduced a mound of evidence showing how gender-affirming care, introduced in slow and deliberate stages, drastically improved childrenâ€™s lives, Heintz said. Heintz also said that this order reads as an implict threat to providers because it equates all trans care to â€œchemical and surgical mutilation,â€ and asks the Department of Justice to review and prioritize laws against female genital mutilation, or the cutting, sewing, or removal of the labia or clitoris for non-medical reasons. Now it was the governmentâ€™s burden to prove, with evidence, that it is the mutilation it claims it is. It could not. The governmentâ€™s lawyer, Vinita Andrapalliyal, argued the President had the constitutional authority to direct his agency heads to take appropriate next steps on a â€œpolicy preference.â€ It is possible the order â€œcould be implemented lawfully,â€ she said, and until an agency revoked any grant, the court did not have to decide, and should wait to see how this â€œshakes out.â€ Her argument fell apart a few minutes later when Judge King started asking simple questions, like: Were all the treatments as â€œirreversibleâ€ as the order claimed they were? â€œNo, I donâ€™t think we specifically say one way or the otherâ€”â€ Vinita Andrapalliyal said. â€œIâ€™m asking you today,â€ King interjected. â€œI donâ€™tâ€”I donâ€™t know, Iâ€™m here todayâ€”â€ â€œYou have not looked into it.â€ â€œIâ€™m here within the lawfulness of the executive orderâ€”â€ â€œThis is part of it,â€ King said. â€œDo you have any evidence that all of the treatments listed in the executive order are irreversible?â€ Andrapalliyal said she had evidence of the Presidentâ€™s policy prerogative to not fund the â€œso-called transition of a child from one sex to another.â€ â€œBut weâ€™re looking at goals hereâ€”irreversible treatment is central to the goals. You havenâ€™t looked into that at all. You donâ€™t have an answer for me today.â€ This carried on for 13 more excruciating minutes. When King asked for an example of the order targeting similar treatment for cisgender people, there was a thirty second pause. When King asked if the government would allow doctors to prescribe puberty blockers, a drug given to both cisgender and transgender children to delay the onset of puberty, to a cisgender boy with prostate cancer, while disallowing doctors from giving the same medication to a transgender girl with the same condition, there was another long pause. After disagreement about the meaning of the text, Andrapalliyal reiterated that the President is asking his agencies to take next steps consistent with the law, and they donâ€™t yet know those steps. King posed another hypothetical: A recently married, 18-year-old cisgender man with Huntingtonâ€™s Disease gets a vasectomy because he does not want to pass it onto his children. Was that included in the governmentâ€™s refusal to support the alteration or removal of an individualâ€™s sex organs to â€œminimize or destroy their natural biological functions?â€ â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Andrapalliyal said. â€œCan you read the text and let me know what you think?â€ King asked. Another pause, which like the others, was filled with snickering from an obviously queer audience. (Before the hearing, activists had circulated a flier encouraging people to â€œpack the court.â€ At 9:20, forty minutes before the hearing, the line for security nearly snaked out the door. Every seat was taken, even in the overflow room.) â€œIâ€™m not a medical provider,â€ Andrapalliyal said. â€œIf you canâ€™t figure it outâ€”how is a medical provider supposed to know that?â€ King said. â€œThis is not a medical text. This is an executive order.â€ After back and forth of when and how medical providers were supposed to determine a personâ€™s birth sex, for which Andrapalliyal had no answers, she said there were a lot of unknowns. â€œMedical providers have no direction on where to go because you canâ€™t read the text and apply it to various facts,â€ King said, sharply exhaling. â€œThis is extremely frustrating, counsel.â€ At courthouse steps, a reporter asked AG Brown what he thought of this exchange. â€œA bit embarrassing,â€ he said to laughter and applause, but he later turned serious. â€œI want to remind people that the Department of Justice was created to defend civil rights,â€ he said. â€œWhat weâ€™re seeing from this President is a specific undermining of its purpose, a specific directive to no longer defend civil rights, and it is upsetting to me, personally and professionally.â€ Indigo, a nonbinary person who responded to the activist call to â€œpack the court,â€ said it was important to show up in numbers to support the community, even just to be a â€œbody in a room.â€ Theyâ€™re also Asian-American, and went through the â€œwhole China virus thingâ€ during COVID-19, so they knew how Trumpâ€™s comments could galvanize people with bigoted views to take violent action. Standing in the courtyard outside, Danni Askini, executive director of the Seattle-based trans advocacy organization Gender Justice League, wondered if the â€œshock and aweâ€ effect of the Trump Administration is their â€œown undoing.â€ â€œTheyâ€™ve pushed so much stuff down on the Department of Justice, and theyâ€™re firing people left and right,â€ she says. â€œWho wants to work in a politicized law firm like the DOJ as it is now? I really feel for the Assistant US Attorney who argued the case.â€ After all, the DOJ essentially failed to make the same case twice this week. On Thursday, US District Judge Brendan Hurson of Maryland also issued a temporary restraining order blocking Trumpâ€™s order. During the hearing, Hurson said he was skeptical that the governmentâ€™s order was not effectively banning care nationwide by threatening to pull funding from hospitals and research institutions that provide or study transgender care for youth and young adults. Patients had received phone calls stopping care, stopping their appointments, stopping their â€œeverything,â€ he said. â€œI donâ€™t know how you can credibly argue that this is not demanding the cessation of funding for gender affirming care.â€ Whether or not hospitals needed to comply with Trumpâ€™s order in the first place is unclear. Executive orders are not laws. Theyâ€™re directives to federal agencies. As of today, Robert F. Kennedy Jr.â€™s Department of Health and Human Services has not issued a new rule on trans care. Even if it had, any policy change would be subject to the Administrative Procedure Act. The rule would undergo public comment. Implementation should take months if not years. However, the Trump administration has a, letâ€™s say, creative approach to current law and administrative procedure. During todayâ€™s hearing, Heintz told Judge King that at least one recipient of a federal grant at the University of Washington received a five sentence notice from Health and Human Services that told them to terminate any program in conflict with the executive order. King remarked that the title of the email indicated it was likely sent to all recipients of those grants. President2 Elon Musk and Vice President JD Vance have openly questioned the judiciaryâ€™s authority over the executive branch. We donâ€™t know what those Yankees teach over at their fancy-schmancy Yale Law School, but that is very much the point of the courts. But Vance is not one to let knowledge get in the way of power. Seattle Childrenâ€™s filed a declaration in support of Brownâ€™s lawsuit, where Jeffrey J. Ojemann, the hospitalâ€™s senior vice president and chief physician executive, argued that losing federal funds would be cataclysmic. He explained the hospitalâ€™s research program employs more than 375 faculty investigators, and 100 postdoctoral scholars, who study every â€œaspect of pediatric health and disease,â€ including childhood cancer and blood disorders, immunotherapy, infectious diseases, neurological disorders and respiratory diseases. Research takes money, a lot of it federal funds: In 2024, the hospital was awarded nearly $185 million in federal research grants. According to a lawyer from the ACLU, Hursonâ€™s decision should give hospitals like Childrenâ€™s the confidence to care for their patients without risking their funding. AG Brown reiterated that point today. â€œI want to encourage all of the providers in this state, in the state of Oregon and the state of Minnesota to get back to work,â€ he said. It appears thatâ€™s already happening. After the hearing, The Stranger checked in with Sarah, the mother of the trans teen whose top surgery Childrenâ€™s postponed last week. Sheâ€™d just gotten a call from the hospital to reschedule her sonâ€™s surgery. Childrenâ€™s did not confirm if it had resumed all forms of gender-affirming care, but thanked AG Brown for filing the complaint â€œso that Seattle Childrenâ€™s has the clarity needed at this time to deliver on our mission while ensuring we operate within all applicable laws.â€ Temporary restraining orders are just that. Temporary. The state will likely seek a preliminary-injunction, an order that will last longer than 14 days.

title: Current Weather Game Center Missing man with autism sparks community rally in Everett months after disappearance
content: Mostly Cloudy 58 72 55 Today 72 55 Sunday 72 56 Monday 73 57 Latest Weathercast Now 58 Sun 72 Mon 73 by KOMO News Staff TOPICS: EVERETT, Wash. â€” Community members are rallying in a powerful show of support to find Jonathan Hoang, a 21-year-old autistic man from Arlington who disappeared four months ago. His family, with the help of national advocates including the Gabby Petito Foundation, is determined to bring him home safely. PREVIOUS COVERAGE | 1st possible sighting of missing man with autism in Kirkland renews hope for family "We need help finding Jonathan, and we canâ€™t do it by ourselves," said Thao Hoang, Jonathan's father. More than 120 days have passed since Jonathan vanished from his family's home, with no trace of him found save for a brief sighting in late June. Surveillance footage from multiple neighbors on the night of June 23 showed a young man resembling Hoang in the South Juanita area near 105th Avenue Northeast and Northeast 112th Street. His family continues to search for answers. "Weâ€™re just wondering what happened. He appeared and then disappeared, and weâ€™re feeling a little frantic right now," said Ann Hoang, Jonathan's mother. The "Honk and Wave" rally, held at the corner of Broadway and Hewitt in Everett, aimed to raise awareness of Jonathan's disappearance and demonstrate community unity. National groups like the Gabby Petito Foundation and 'Light the Way' joined local volunteers to spread awareness. "It was a godsend when they contacted us and said 'Hey, we would like to help you,' and it was such a big relief for us because, like Ann said, we were desperate. It felt like we were alone," Thao said. Community members have also reached out to offer assistance. "People reach out to us and ask how can we help find Jonathan and bringing awareness is really the key," Thao added. Jonathan, who is autistic and verbal but considered vulnerable, was last credibly sighted just over a month ago on a home security camera in Kirkland. His family believes he is still alive and in need of help. Family and supporting organizations have also stated they believe Jonathan was most likely coerced or taken from his home. RELATED | Search intensifies for missing 21-year-old man with autism last seen in Arlington A $100,000 reward remains available for information leading to Jonathan's discovery. For more information, visit www.findjonathan.com.

title: Thing Festival Cancels One Weekend Due to ICE Concerns Just Can't Get Enough?
content: Earlier today, the THING Festival announced via social media that it had â€œmade the very difficult decisionâ€ to cancel its August 16 date, which had been â€œspecially curated to showcase some of musicâ€™s most exceptional Latinx and Spanish-language artists.â€ The statement read, â€œCommunity safety concerns have greatly reduced ticket sales, and the uncertainty about artistsâ€™ ability to secure the necessary visas has led to our decision. We stand with our broader community and remain committed to prioritizing attendee and artist safety, and to ensure our events are a positive and memorable arts experience. We want to sincerely thank the artists, our community partners and sponsors, and everyone behind the scenes who worked tirelessly to bring this unique event to life.â€ The organization also noted that all August 16 ticket holders should expect to see refunds returned to their original forms of payment within the next seven to 10 business days. THING was founded in 2019 and has traditionally been a three-day-long festival in the past, but this year, the organization opted for a new format with a series of events set to take place at Remlinger Farms in Carnation, Washington across four weekends in August. Chilean-Mexican pop singer Mon Laferte was slated to headline the August 16 lineup, along with Yahritza y Su Esencia, Thee Sinseers, RubÃ©n AlbarrÃ¡n, AngÃ©lica Garcia, Terror/Cactus and Pahua, and Lucia Flors-Wiseman. The festival isnâ€™t the first event to be called off recently under similar circumstances. In June, the Duwamish River Community Coalition canceled the Duwamish River Festival in the South Park neighborhood due to speculation that ICE might target it, and earlier this month, the Burien nonprofit Joyas Mestizas announced that they would cancel the 2025 Pacific Northwest FolklÃ³rico Festival, writing, â€œWe are angry at the ICE raids and racist immigration policies that tear families apart, and in canceling our event we commit to prioritizing the safety of our community. As a community organization born from the 20th-century freedom movements, Joyas Mestizas not only understands the arts as essential to pushing against oppression but recognizes folkloricoâ€™s continued existence as a testament to our coming together. While we stand firm in our origins, the urgency of our communityâ€™s need for safety and security demands immediate action.â€ Just earlier this week, Fernando Rocha, the theater manager at Juanita High School was detained by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement. KUOW reported last week that King County passed a resolution on Tuesday, July 15, that would support protections for immigrants and prevent county agencies from sharing sensitive data that could lead to immigrant enforcement. Weâ€™ve reached out to THING Festivalâ€™s organizers for comment and will update this article if we hear back. As always, fuck ICE.

title: Current Weather Game Center Semi-truck consumed by flames on SR 18, emergency crews on the scene
content: Partly Cloudy 70 70 56 Today 70 56 Sunday 72 56 Monday 73 57 Latest Weathercast Now 70 Sun 72 Mon 73 by KOMO News Staff TOPICS: MAPLE VALLEY, Wash. â€” Traffic cameras spotted a semi-truck go up in flames on SR 18 in Maple Valley late Saturday morning. Footage sourced from a WSDOT traffic camera showed the truck pulled over to the side of the road on 236th Ave. SE, , with black smoke billowing from the front. Flames rapidly began to lick up the side of the truck and onto the top, as well as surrounding brush on the embankment. Puget Sound Fire crews were on the scene as of 11:35 a.m., and KOMO News has reached out for more information. WSDOT stated the right lane is blocked on westbound SR 18, with no estimated time of reopening. It will be slow going in this area for some time. Travelers should use caution in the area, and be prepared for traffic delays.

title: Current Weather Game Center Car crashes into University Place restaurant twice in failed towing attempt
content: Cloudy 62 75 57 Today 75 57 Sunday 72 57 Monday 73 58 Latest Weathercast Now 62 Sun 72 Mon 73 by KOMO News Staff TOPICS: SEATTLE â€” A bizarre series of events unfolded early on July 30 when a car crashed into the UP Pho and Teriyaki restaurant twice in quick succession, causing significant damage to the entrance. Deputies responded to the scene on July 30 around 6 a.m. to find the vehicle abandoned in the parking lot. According to surveillance footage, the maroon car had been parked at a nearby AutoZone since the previous day. The driver had informed employees that the vehicle was not functioning properly and that he would return to tow it. At approximately 3:45 a.m., a white Honda Pilot with a dolly attempted to tow the maroon car. The vehicle was initially pulled from its parking spot around 5:15 a.m., but the tow strap failed, leaving it at the far end of the parking lot. A second attempt to secure the vehicle around 5:50 a.m. resulted in the vehicle rolling down the lot and crashing into the restaurant. The Honda driver made a third attempt to tow the vehicle, but the strap broke again, causing the car to crash into the restaurant a second time. Ultimately, the driver and a female passenger abandoned the maroon car after it became stuck along a retention wall and curb. University Place Deputies are investigating the incident as a hit-and-run collision and are seeking assistance from the public. They urge anyone who recognizes the white Honda Pilot or the female passenger involved to come forward.

title: Current Weather Game Center Seattle Kraken hockey player, sea troll charged by grizzly bear during Alaska fishing trip
content: Mostly Cloudy 69 70 57 Today 70 57 Monday 74 58 Tuesday 71 61 Latest Weathercast Now 69 Mon 74 Tue 71 by KOMO News Staff TOPICS: ANCHORAGE, Alaska â€” The Seattle Kraken hockey team and their sea troll mascot Buoy had quite the heart-racing experience after a grizzly bear charged them during a fly fishing excursion. The Kraken were in Anchorage for their annual partnership trip with the Bristol Bay Native Corporation, a union that brings a blend of hockey and community engagement to hockey fans in Alaska. RELATED | Seattle Kraken in the news - matches, players, and more The week-long event included a hockey camp hosted by the Anchorage Hockey Academy. The camp featured Kraken forward John Hayden, the team's mascot Buoy, and various youth hockey coaches from the Kraken organization. However, during a fly fishing excursion on June 25 in Katmai National Park, an uninvited guest showed up - a grizzly bear. Video provided by Kraken shows the bear watching the fisherpeople from the other side of the shallow river. As its presence is flagged and everyone begins to quickly evacuate the water, the bear is seen advancing on them, rushing toward the group and sending spray flying before veering away again. It seemed particularly interested in the blue-haired Buouy, who, ever the good sport, never stopped smiling as he slogged away to safety. "I want to blame it on Buoy. They were pretty interested in his whole look. We got out of it okay, but it was a close call," Hayden said. During the trip, the Kraken visited their 2025 Make-A-Wish recipient, Caleb, and his family. The team revealed that Caleb and his family would be traveling to Seattle for a game and a special Kraken experience in January. The Seattle Kraken have partnered with the Bristol Bay Native Corporation for the past four years, focusing on growing youth hockey in Alaska and promoting sustainability goals in the Pacific Northwest region and beyond.
